question: Question_01_(b)
statement:
Let

\[A = \begin{bmatrix}
1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & a & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 2
\end{bmatrix}\]

where \emph{a} is a real number.

\textbf{(b)} For what values of \emph{a} (if any) is \emph{cond(A)} not
defined? Give a reason.
sols:
Please refer to
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2010/Question_01_(a)}{part
(a)} regarding the computation of $\parallel A\parallel$

Recall that

$\text{cond}(A) = \parallel A\parallel \cdot \parallel A^{-1}\parallel$

With \emph{A} being a diagonal matrix, its inverse is given by:

$A^{-1} = \begin{bmatrix}
1 & 0 & 0\\ 
0 & \frac{1}{a} & 0\\ 
0 & 0 & \frac{1}{2}
\end{bmatrix}$

valid for all values where \emph{a} is nonzero. When \emph{a} is zero,
this inverse, and hence cond(A) is undefined. Similar to
$\parallel A\parallel$ , we have
$\parallel A^{-1}\parallel = \max\{\parallel 1\parallel ,\parallel \frac{1}{a}\parallel ,\parallel \frac{1}{2}\parallel \}$
and these are defined for all nonzer values of \emph{a}.

So cond(A) is defined for all values of a, except a = 0.
